summary.seg: This manuscript contains an abridgement of statutes from the reign of King Edward III (reg. 1327–1377), written in Latin and French. A single medical recipe was added in the 15th century to some blank space after the end of the Statute of Ireland: entitled 'To remove a blemish in the eye' ('Ad delendam maculam in Oculo'), it prescribes a herbal remedy comprising 'þynroske', 'lushes', red fennel, celandine, rosemary, sage and other plants, which were to be crushed together and tempered with breast milk from a woman who has given birth to a male child. This concoction should then be wrung through a linen cloth and applied to the sore eye.

It is not unusual to find such cures in manuscripts that otherwise have no medical contents. Nevertheless, it is noticeable that legal manuscripts were a frequent repository for this kind of information, with several other examples included among the corpus covered by the Curious Cures project. For example, Cambridge, University Library, MS Add. 2994 - a legal compendium comprising the Novel Tenures, the Natura brevium and various other standard texts, owned and partly written by Edward Cushyn (fl. 1512) - contains a collection of fifteen remedies for gout. Cambridge, University Library, MS Add. 7912 - a legal commonplace book compiled by Sir Edmund Jenney (d. 1522) and members of his family - has recipes to purge excess phlegm or choler, cures for breathlessness ('schortnes of wynd') and the pestilence, and a 'gargarison for the fumys in the head'. Cambridge, University Library, MS Ee.1.3 - principally a copy of Common Pleas entries compiled by Simon Elryngton of Hackney (d. 1481/85) - has recipes for a plaster to stop aches, laxatives and costives, cures for quartan fever, migraine and burns. Similarly, Cambridge, University Library, MS Ee.5.18 - a compilation of Readings and other legal texts copied wholly or largely by Walter Atwell (fl. c. 1520), lawyer of Staple Inn - also includes a mnemonic about stranguary, diarrhoea and dysentery and a recipe for purging the humours, both attributed to the apothecary John Cokkys (d. 1475).

Rather than attributing this pattern to lawyerly hypochondria, a more likely explanation is that medieval legal practitioners were literate men, had parchment or paper and pen to hand, and were accustomed to writing useful information down: in all of the above manuscripts, the recipes were copied into blank space around the legal texts that formed their principal contents. These notes might be prescriptions they had received from medical practitioners or which were recommended to them by acquaintances. As professionals, lawyers also possessed the means to pay for medical treatments, though the fact they troubled to record them suggests that they or their households may have tried to make the formulations themselves. In the case of MS Kk.6.6, one can easily imagine a medieval lawyer suffering from sore eyes as a consequence of poring over the necessities of legal bureaucracy in poorly lit surroundings.

Dr James Freeman
Medieval Manuscripts Specialist
Cambridge University Library

msItem.title: Precedents of writs founded on the Ordinance of the Labourers 1349, and a commission for justices of labourers in the parts of Holland, Linconshire
Chronological abridgement of statutes, 1-45 Edward III
msItem.incipit: 9r Fait asauoir qe lan le Roi
msItem.explicit: 45v come ad este use avaunt cez hurez etcaetera

msItem.title: Nota exceptionis [Modus exceptionum]
msItem.incipit: 45r Notandum quod quatuor modis dicitur exceptio
msItem.explicit: 46r et post illam non valeant ad aliam resortire responcionem
msItem.note: For other copies of this mnemonic note see Baker and Ringrose, Catalogue of English Legal Manuscripts (1996), pp. 96-97.

msItem.title: Statute of Ireland (31 Edward III, statute 4)
msItem.incipit: 47r Edwardus etcaetera Archiepiscopis Abbatibus Prioribus Ministri nostri tam maioribus quam minoribus et quibuscumque aliis de terra nostra Hibernia fidelibus nostris
msItem.explicit: 55v In cuius rei testimonium etcaetera Rege apud Westmonasterium vicesimo sexto die Octobri per ipsum et consilium etcaetera

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.explicit: 55v and wryng all this throw a lynnyn cloþ and þen put hit euery day in to the sore eyy

listBibl.bibl: Connolly, Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo) (2009), p. 281

msItem.title: 31 Edward III, statute 1, c. 15 (abridged)
msItem.incipit: 56r Anno xxxio. Item, pur ceo que lez viscountes ount vse de tenir lour tourns en qaresme
msItem.explicit: 56ret sils lez teignent en autre manere qadonqes ils perdent lours tourne par le temps

msItem.title: Statutum de moneta
msItem.incipit: 56r Per discretionem totius Anglie fuit mensura domini regis composita videlicet quod denarius Anglicus qui vocatur sterlingus rotundus et sine tonsura ponderabit xxxii grana frumenti rubij et rotundi in medio spice
msItem.explicit: 58v Et Clx partice qualitercumque tacent faciunt j acre terre
msItem.note: For other copies of this mnemonic note see Baker and Ringrose, Catalogue of English Legal Manuscripts (1996), p. 96.

msItem.title: Note from the year book for the Easter term of 17 Edward III
msItem.incipit: 58v En case de corone si le defendant challenge generalment iii enquestez saunz cause
msItem.explicit: 58v et ne serra pas noumbre vt patet in anno xvijo Edwardi tercij termino Pasche
msItem.note: For an edition of the text from another manuscript, see Year Books of the Reign of King Edward the Third: Year XVII, ed. by Luke Owen Pike, Rolls Series 31 (London: Printed by Mackie for Her Majesty's Stationery Office, 1901), p. 281, pl. 8.

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos

supportDesc.condition: Some staining, especially on ff. 50v-51r, but without affecting the text

layout.seg: Ruling in crayon, frame only. Single columns. 22-31 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Writen in several current Anglicana hands, the main ones are on ff. 2r-6v; 9r-21v; 21v-45v; 47r-52r; 52r-52v.
The medical recipe on f. 55v is written in an Anglicana script.

decoNote.p: One heading in blue ink on f. 9r.
Paragraph marks in red or blue.

binding.p: Full white leather binding that replaces the old binding described by Baker and Ringrose, Catalogue of English Legal Manuscripts (1987), 422.

The previous 18th-century binding is kept separately: quarter brown leather with marbled paper sides with the donation bookplate engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736 on the inside of the upper cover; the covers contains 10 flyleaves (ff. i-x) and a spine label of Red Russia leather gold-stamped with the letters 'Edward 3.D. M.S.' (spine label)

provenance.p: Richard Pygot (fl. 15th century) Pygot, Richard, fl. 15th century : his name inscribed in a 15th-century hand on f. 58v: 'per me Ricardum Pygot'.
John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : no. 783 (f. 1r) in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697).

acquisition.p: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 : donation bookplate engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736 on the inside upper cover of the 18th-century binding.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on the description provided by John Baker and Jayne Ringrose, Catalogue of English Legal Manuscripts in Cambridge University Library (1996) (used here by kind permission of the Boydell Press).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

monogr.title: Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo)

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer, Cambridge University Library
